subject: Re: [junit] Re:How to use JUnit return String[]
msgSnippet: It s not quite clear what you re trying to test. Your code below won t compile.  Do you want to test if your method returns the expected string array? As far
messageBody:
It's not quite clear what you're trying to test. Your code below won't
compile. Do you want to test if your method returns the expected string
array? As far as I know, JUnit doesn't provide any direct method of
testing string arrays for equality, but it should be easy to write a
helper method that does that, returning a boolean depnding on the
result. For example,

private boolean stringArraysEqual(String[] expected, String[] actual) {
//Your code here
}

Then your test code could look like:

String[] expected = { "Foo1", "Foo2" };
String[] result = testClass.getMandatoryPararmeters();

assertTrue(stringArraysEqual(expected, result);

John


kavitha arumugam wrote:

>Hi All,
>

>returning String is working. But i have no idea String
>[].
>
>
>Java Code:
>public String[] getMandatoryParameters(){
> return new String[]{"SourceString"};
> }
>
>JUnit code: here testclass calling java class already
>initialized in setup
>public void testgetMandatoryParameters()
> {
> String getMandatoryParam = {"SourceString"};
> assertEquals( testClass.getMandatoryParameters ),
>getMandatoryParam);
> }
>
>I will appreciate ur help.
>Cheers,
>Kavitha
